thread.title: Seahawks blow yet another fourth-quarter lead, lose 27-23 to Panthers to fall to 2-4
thread.title_full: Seahawks blow yet another fourth-quarter lead, lose 27-23 to Panthers to fall to 2-4

author:
Gregg Bell 
Staff writer
title: Seahawks blow yet another fourth-quarter lead, lose 27-23 to Panthers to fall to 2-4
text:
October 18, 2015 Seahawks blow yet another fourth-quarter lead, lose 27-23 to Panthers to fall to 2-4 Carolina Panthers tight end Greg Olsen, right, celebrates with teammates Fozzy Whittaker, left, and Corey Brown (10) after Olsen caught a pass for a touchdown in the second half of an NFL football game, Sunday, Oct. 18, 2015, in Seattle. Elaine Thompson AP i SEATTLE 
They still couldn’t finish. So now, are the Seahawks finished? 
After a week spent preaching and coaching and pleading and repeating coach Pete Carroll’s mantra-gone-bad, the Seahawks had a 23-14 lead in the fourth quarter. 
Then that defense allowed Carolina’s third and fourth 80-yard touchdown drive Sunday. The killer scene: Earl Thomas and Richard Sherman, Seattle’s two All-Pro cover men, angrily pointing and gesturing to each other while tight end Greg Olsen caught the 26-yard touchdown pass with 32 seconds left. 
That sent the undefeated Panthers a stunning, 27-23 victory – and the Seahawks to another, perhaps season-altering defeat in the final minutes and seconds. 
Seattle (2-4) has been outscored 48-9 in the fourth quarters of its last five games. That includes 13-3 on Sunday. 
The defense’s latest collapse came on the same route concept with which Cincinnati doomed the Seahawks in a come-from-behind win in overtime the week before: the tight end deep down the hash marks, with diversion routes short in front of that. 
The Seahawks wasted Jimmy Graham setting his Seahawk high with 140 yards on eight receptions in a season-high 12 targets. Marshawn Lynch returned from missing two games with a strained hamstring to run for his first touchdown since February’s Super Bowl. Seattle got two more interceptions, by Thomas and Kam Chancellor after their bad game at Cincinnati. 
Yet the two-time defending NFC champions blew a lead in the fourth quarter for the sixth time in eight games dating to January’s NFC championship. 
When it ended, with Doug Baldwin hopelessly pitching back a lateral trying to move the ball out of his own end as time expired, many in the record crowd of 69,020 at CenturyLink Field booed.
